# Security And Justice Regulations
[bold]Security and Justice Regulations[/bold] Are rules that Security must enforce, and that Justice must uphold. In this section, you will find these paragraphs:
[textlink="Security Jurisdiction" link="SecurityJurisdiction"] is the rules of Legal Authority relating to Security members. Such as [bold]being under tresspass laws unless they believe a crime is being commited.[/bold]
[textlink="Probable Cause" link="ProbableCause"] is a term that makes sure that Security officers can not willingly investigate or enforce law without a reason. They always need to have a reason like witnessing a crime being committed.
[textlink="Rules Of Engagement" link="RulesOfEngagement"] states the reasons on [bold]when Security personnel are allowed to use lethal force.[/bold]
[textlink="Martial Law" link="MartialLaw"] is a special law [bold]declared by Central Command[/bold] during times of crisis. This gives security the ability to preform many actions without a warrant and disregard the Rules Of Engagement.
[textlink="Armory Procedure" link="ArmoryProcedure"] are the guidelines for when security can have access to weaponry from the armory.
[textlink="Treatment of Prisoners" link="TreatmentOfPrisoners"] is the rights of prisoners and how they are meant to be treated while serving their sentence.
[textlink="Arrest and Sentencing" link="ArrestandSentencing"] is how to correctly arrest and sentence the accused.
[textlink="Appeals, Parole, Pardons" link="AppealsParolePardons"] is when an inmate is to be released, along with what each term means.
[textlink="Pressing Criminal Charges" link="PressingCriminalCharges"] is how to legally press charges against someone.
[textlink="Warrants" link="Warrants"] is the act of paperwork to commit legal searches or legal arrests.
[textlink="Injunctions" link="Injunctions"] is how the Chief Justice, Commanding Officer or a Judge can authorise things like Restraining Orders.
